as a criterion by which to ascertain where or between what 
surfaces such phenomena are formed: for instance, if 
Newtonian Rings are seen in the lightest border of the 
before mentioned shadow thrown on two or more slips 
of plate glass or Lenses laid on each other; it is a proof 
that such phenomena are formed between the lower 
surface of the upper glass & the upper surface of the second 
glass; & if seen in the second shadow, it is equally a  proof of 
their being formed between the lower surface of the second 
glass & upper surface of the third glass or Lens &c. 
In the mean time, as the terms <u>primary transmitted 
& reflected <\u> rings will frequently occur, it may be necessary 
to define their meaning. Several other phenomena will also 
be noticed hereafter which will be explained with more 
propriety as they occur. 
Ex. 5. Primary or Newtonian rings are those formed between 
two lenses, or between a flat glass & a lens when pressed to-
gether, & are seen by reflected light. 
Ex. 6. Transmitted rings are seen by transmitted light, when 
the lenses between which they are formed are held between 
the light & the eye; & their colours altho in the same order 
as those of primaries are always alternate therto. for 
example, if the central spot of the primary set of rings is 
dark, that of the transmitted set will be white or trans-
parent; if the former is red, that of the latter will be green, 
& yellow will be opposed to violet, &c. and this holds true 
with respect to all the colours of every ring composing 
both sets. 
Ex 7. Another mode of seeing transmitted Rings is by re-
flection from the lower internal surface of the lower of the 
two glasses between which primaries are formed. if 
this apparatus is laid horizontally on a Table, exposed 
to the light of a window, & if the shadow of the black card 
before mentioned is brought over it, the primary set 
will appear in the first, & the transmitted set in the 
second shadow; & in this way they are seen to most 
advantage.
